questions.text: Why is ultrasound classified as non-ionizing imaging?
questions.explanation: The lecture introduces ultrasound as "imaging with sound", i.e. mechanical pressure waves rather than ionizing radiation.

questions.text: What frequency range is typically used in diagnostic ultrasound?
questions.explanation: Slide "Wave basics" states: Diagnostic ultrasound operates roughly between 2.5 and 20 MHz.

questions.text: What type of wave is primarily used for medical ultrasound imaging?
questions.explanation: Slides on wave types explain that ultrasound imaging uses longitudinal compressional waves in tissue.

questions.text: What physical quantity determines acoustic impedance?
questions.explanation: Slide "Acoustic impedance" defines Z = ρ · c, where ρ is density and c is speed of sound.

questions.text: Why does bone appear bright in ultrasound images?
questions.explanation: Slides show that large impedance differences (e.g., soft tissue–bone) cause strong reflection.

questions.text: What determines the fraction of reflected ultrasound at a tissue interface?
questions.explanation: The reflection coefficient R depends on the impedance difference Z₂ − Z₁, as shown in the specular reflection slides.

questions.text: Why does ultrasound gel improve image quality?

options.B: It reduces impedance mismatch between probe and skin

questions.explanation: Gel removes the large air–skin impedance mismatch that would otherwise cause near-total reflection.

questions.text: What causes speckle patterns in ultrasound images?
questions.explanation: The wave scattering slide states that particles smaller than the wavelength cause diffuse scattering, producing speckle.

questions.text: Why is attenuation frequency-dependent in ultrasound?

options.B: Higher frequencies are absorbed more strongly

questions.explanation: Slide "Wave energy absorption" shows attenuation α = α₀ fⁿ, increasing with frequency.

questions.text: What trade-off exists when increasing ultrasound frequency?
questions.explanation: Higher frequency improves resolution (shorter wavelength) but increases attenuation, reducing penetration.

questions.text: What principle allows depth estimation in B-mode ultrasound?
questions.explanation: The pulse-echo principle uses echo return time to estimate axial depth.

questions.text: Why is the speed of sound assumed constant in ultrasound imaging?

options.A: It is exactly the same in all tissues

questions.explanation: Beamforming assumes a constant speed of sound (~1540 m/s) to compute delays.

questions.text: What is beamforming in ultrasound?

options.B: Focusing sound using delays across array elements

questions.explanation: Beamforming excites multiple elements with specific delays to create and focus beams.

questions.text: Which beamforming method is considered the baseline approach?
questions.explanation: The lecture introduces Delay-And-Sum as the standard beamforming strategy.

questions.text: What is the main limitation of DAS beamforming?
questions.explanation: Advanced beamforming slides state that constant speed and homogeneity assumptions often do not hold.

questions.text: Why does DMAS beamforming improve image quality?
questions.explanation: DMAS exploits correlation between channels, enhancing coherent signals.

questions.text: What does the Point Spread Function (PSF) describe?

options.B: System response to a point scatterer

questions.explanation: The PSF is described as the system’s response to a point scatterer.

questions.text: What does FWHM measure in ultrasound imaging?
questions.explanation: Full Width at Half Maximum is used to quantify axial and lateral resolution.

questions.text: Why is apodization applied in beamforming?
questions.explanation: Apodization weights reduce side lobes at the cost of slightly reduced resolution.

questions.text: Which imaging strategy enables ultrafast ultrasound?
questions.explanation: Planewave imaging forms an entire image from a single transmit, enabling ultrafast acquisition.

questions.text: Why does planewave imaging initially have lower image quality?
questions.explanation: Unfocused transmit produces lower receive amplitudes, as shown in the planewave vs scanline slides.

questions.text: How is planewave image quality typically improved?
questions.explanation: Multiple steered planewaves are combined to improve resolution and SNR.

questions.text: What does Time Gain Compensation (TGC) correct for?
questions.explanation: TGC compensates for increasing attenuation as sound travels deeper into tissue.

questions.text: Why is log-compression applied in B-mode imaging?
questions.explanation: Log-compression maps large dynamic ranges into displayable grayscale values.

questions.text: What physical effect enables Doppler ultrasound?
questions.explanation: The Doppler equation relates frequency shift to particle velocity.

questions.text: Why does Doppler angle matter?
questions.explanation: The Doppler equation includes a cos(θ) term, making angle estimation critical.

questions.text: Which transducer type is best suited for deep abdominal imaging?
questions.explanation: Curvilinear arrays operate at lower frequencies, providing higher penetration.

questions.text: Which probe is used for cardiac imaging through small acoustic windows?
questions.explanation: Phased arrays allow electronic beam steering through small acoustic windows.

questions.text: Why do intravascular probes operate at very high frequencies?

options.B: Improve axial resolution at shallow depth

questions.explanation: Intravascular probes sacrifice penetration for very high spatial resolution.

questions.text: What limits lateral resolution in ultrasound imaging?
questions.explanation: Lateral resolution depends on beam width, governed by focusing and aperture.

questions.text: What limits axial resolution?
questions.explanation: Shorter pulses improve axial resolution by reducing echo overlap.

questions.text: Why is ultrasound well suited for real-time imaging?
questions.explanation: Ultrasound supports high frame rates due to rapid transmit–receive cycles.

questions.text: What is a major limitation of ultrasound imaging?
questions.explanation: Clinical practice highlights strong operator dependence in ultrasound.

questions.text: Why is bone difficult to image beyond its surface?
questions.explanation: Bone strongly reflects and absorbs ultrasound, preventing penetration.

questions.text: What is the overarching message of the ultrasound lecture?
questions.explanation: The lecture repeatedly emphasizes trade-offs between resolution, penetration, and frame rate.
